title: Who is the smartest human being that's ever lived? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to Intelligence Quotient scores, the smartest human being that has ever lived is William James Sidis.  He was born in New York on April 1, 1898 and he is still considered the person with the highest Intelligence Quotient of all times with an (alleged) outstanding score of about 200 (just to compare, a normal person's IQ is around 100 and Einstein's IQ is estimated to be 160-190). From the first months of his life, Sidis showed an incredibly precocious intellectual development. At six months, the young William already started to speak, at 18 months he was reading the newspaper, and at four years old he already spoke Latin. The young man was so talented that when he was eight years old his math skills were superior to his father’s. Also at that age, he passed the admission test to the University of Harvard, that he was forced to give up on because he was too young at the time. Two years later, however, he was admitted, and in June 18, 1914, he graduated with honours in Literature. Despite a degree in letters, Sidis began teaching three scientific subjects: Euclidean geometry, non-Euclidean geometry, and trigonometry. The situation in his family worsened in that period, though: the relationship with his father became more and more tense, but the breaking point was reached when he participated in a workers' manifestation on May 1, 1919, and was consequently arrested. The news was widely reported, and William declared himself a socialist and an atheist, while the prosecution imposed on him eighteen months in prison and a $ 5,000 deposit (paid by his his friend Leverett Saltonstall). Thanks to his father's intervention, who made a deal with the judge, the case was dismissed. After the event, the parents hospitalised William in a mental clinic that the father, a renowned psychiatrist, owned. The relationship between William and his father finally broke off, and the young genius moved away, to lead a "normal" life as a clerk. He died of a cerebral haemorrhage at age 46 in 1944. It is rumoured that he could speak fluently 40 languages and was able to learn one in three days. While serving his ordinary life, Sidis continued to write: he wrote under a pseudonym over 89 items on the newspapers. In the book "Animated World and Inanimate World" (1920) he anticipated the concept of "black hole". The large number of cover pages in his house suggests that the books found are only a small portion of the whole production of Sidis. Although Sidis did not contribute immensely to scientific progress or made life-changing discoveries, he was undoubtedly smart. As many others have said before me, defining intelligence or smartness is a very complex task, as there are many different types of skills related to this topic. Therefore, I thought that the most arbitrary way to respond to the question was to base my answer on Intelligence Quotient scores, which are supposed to give an idea of smartness alone, without taking into consideration personal successes or achievements of an individual. Edit: This website might also help: Was William James Sidis the Smartest Man on Earth Edit 2: Several people have (rightfully) pointed out that such a high IQ score is, to put it in simple terms, scientifically and mathematically impossible to calculate, as with a mean of 100 the standard deviation does not add up. Several websites contain this information, but if someone has the correct IQ score, I welcome it by all means. The IQ score is allegedly an estimate, I invite you to take it as such. I edited my answer writing that his IQ could be around 200, which seems more plausible. The simple reason why we cannot know who is the smartest person who ever lived is because (in terms of IQ scores) it would require every single person that has ever stepped foot on Earth to take one. And that is simply impossible.
